article.title: Mobile Design Systems at Scale
article.subtitle: Lessons learned from managing enterprise mobile design systems at Fortune 500 companies like USAA and Progressive Insurance, where consistency meets the chaos of 50+ development teams.

executiveSummary.title: Executive Summary
executiveSummary.content: Enterprise mobile design systems aren't just about UI consistency—they're about organizational transformation. After leading design system initiatives at USAA (50+ teams) and Progressive Insurance (legal compliance systems), I've learned that successful design systems solve people problems, not just design problems.

keyFindings.title: Adoption Through Value
keyFindings.description: Teams adopt systems that make their work easier, not because they're mandated to use them.

keyFindings.title: Living Documentation
keyFindings.description: Static comprehensive docs become outdated quickly. Collaborative, contextual documentation stays relevant.

keyFindings.title: Governance as Collaboration
keyFindings.description: Successful systems enable contribution and community rather than controlling from the center.

keyFindings.title: Relationship Metrics Matter
keyFindings.description: System health includes team satisfaction and advocacy, not just adoption rates and compliance.

sections.title: The Scale Challenge
sections.content: When you're designing for one app, you control the variables. When you're designing for 50+ teams across multiple business units, the variables control you.

sections.title: Deep Dive: USAA Implementation Strategy
sections.description: Instead of building a comprehensive system upfront and mandating adoption, we took an advocacy-driven approach that started with high-pain teams and grew through demonstrated value.

timeline.description: Identified teams struggling with accessibility compliance. Our system solved their immediate pain point, turning them into advocates.
Focused on components that solved specific, high-value problems: accessibility compliance, cross-platform consistency, onboarding speed.
Components included built-in validation, accessibility features, error handling, analytics tracking, and A/B testing hooks.
Teams adopted because it made work easier, not because they had to. Pilot teams became advocates to peer teams.
